If angle is measured in radians then the formula for arc length=theta*radius, as radius=1, arc length=theta, Now as angle theta gets closer to 0, arc length and that straight line, i.e. sin(theta), sits on top of each other making sin(theta) = arc length, so that is why sin(theta)/theta=1, as value of both sin(theta) & theta becomes equal.  and NOW as those two quantities are equal, it makes cos(theta)= radius= 1. and when calculated (1-cos(theta)/theta)=(1-1/theta)=(0/theta). and 0/anything=0. In the case where x approaches 0 in the expression of (cosx-1)/x, one can find the value of the expression using geometric intuition.  When "angle x" approaches 0 then the arc length "x" becomes equal to sinx, just as Professor explained in the video. But (cosx-1)/x is another nut to crack.  Let there be a single triangle made by the radius of the unit circle and the x-axis with hypotenuse "H", adjacent side "A" and opposite side "P". Let the angle made by the radius to the x-axis be "x". Now let's take a look at (cosx-1)/x  We know from Professor's explanation that Arc length "x"= sinx (when x approaches 0), so put the value of x=sinx in (cosx-1)/x, and we can write (cosx-1)/x as:  (cosx-1)/sinx Rearrange it as:  (Cosx/sinx) - (1/sinx) Note that (Cosx/sinx)=A/P and (1/sinx)=H/P {basic definitions}  (cosx-1)/x= (A/P)-(H/P)=(A-H)/P  Now take a look at Hypotenuse and the Adjacent side. As angle x gets smaller and smaller, Hypotenuse moves towards the adjacent and when x becomes infinitesimally small, Hypotenuse "H" will nearly become equal to Adjacent "A" ( or you can say that "H" will nearly superimpose on "A")  Therefore H=A for a very small angle x. So : (cosx-1)/x       =(A-A)/P=0  P.S》I thought about sharing this because there were a lot comments regarding this problem. I'm not trying to act like a nerd or genius, as I have been learning calculus for only some time and and it is pretty obvious that my skill is infinitesimally weak with respect to that of the Professors of MIT. This is what I've leart from his geometrical approach.

There are a lot of comments that some of the Prof.'s explanations are not rigorous enough. MIT has 2 or 3 levels of introductory calculus. This one is for freshmen with little or no high school calculus, and who will probably major in eng. where the key is to get the right answer rather than to be rigorously correct. If you go to the OCW website, you can find the one aimed at students who want to major in math or physics. It's totally different and much harder.

I always found it interesting how the US system of teaching calculus has evolved into two subjects - calculus and real analysis. I guess the motivation for calculus is to introduce some of the concepts and build the practical skill of calculating derivatives, integrals and apply them to analysis of functions and generally solving practical problems. The rigorous introduction of the subject is left to real analysis which I guess not all students learn. For me, analysis became clear once I looked into how the subject developed over time, how Newton/Leibniz saw the connection between the derivative and the integral. I always wondered why all those people were so busy with calculating areas and why the tangent was something they were interested in. Also, the limit process always looked as a cheat until the moment someone suggested it was a best approximation, the way to do away with infinity and replace it with the nearest best approximation. Just wondering if calculus presented in such a form rises more questions than it answers.. I guess the joy of applying the method to different problems overshadows the gaps here and there..

When you plug in sin(30º) and sin(pi/6), in both cases you are going the get the same answer =1/2   IF you set your calculator in degrees, and in radians, respectively.  If you set your calculator in degrees, you are going to get sin(30º)= 1/2, but when replacing a θ alone in an equation, you are going to plug the number 30, which is NOT correct. The correct way is setting your calculator in radians, so you get sin(pi/6)= 1/2, and when replacing θ alone in an equation, you plug in pi/6, which is approximately 0.524.

I must say that I have been very disappointed by this lecture series so far. I am already familiar with single variable calculus. However, I am watching this series to review for some future classes (things like multivariable calculus and real analysis).   However, here are some things I have noticed. Would that this instructor had spent some more time on the more rigorous concepts of limits and squeeze theorem, he would not have had to spend so much time trying to justify the proofs of the main two limits of this lecture. In addition to this, his students would be better prepared for future mathematics. As it stands, these students are really at a loss when it comes to their future.  I would really hope that instructors learn from this. Spend more time on the things you need to rigorously justify your claim: the foundations. If the ideas are glossed over, then everyone loses. Students don't understand why something is true, and so they become convinced that what the professor is doing is some kind of witchcraft that makes no sense. Please, if you are an instructor and you are reading this, work on the fundamentals!

You can NOT define the derivative as the slope of the tangent line.  You have got it backwards.  The slope of the tangent line is equal to the value of the derivative, which value is defined by calculation.

for the proof of the limit of (1-cos(x))/x - > 0, why doesn't he just use the sin(x)/x limit he just used beforehand?  Seriously,  take the expression for: sin^2(x/2) is equivalent to (1/2)(1-cos(x)), multiply both sides of the identity by 2,  then bring in the x denominator, and divide top and bottom of left side by 2, giving: (sin(x/2))(sin(x/2)/(x/2)).  Limit of a product is product of limits = (0)(1) = 0?  I know the answer is to prove it geometrically,  however he could prove it with identities, and tell the student to look up a book if they required a more rigorous explanation - assuming that's not in an exam!  Note: I do really like these videos.

I always found it hard to grasp the concepts of limits, especially when it looked like 0/0 but I learned that you should never think of it as 0/0 because really, that is an undefined number and what is important is that the quantity in the limit tends towards 0, infinity or some other number for that matter.  The professor should maybe have emphasised this when addressing the students question about sin(dx)/dx -> 1 because sin(0)/0 is really an undefined number.

For 13 minutes (21:00-34:30), Professor Jerison tries to justify (1-cos x)/x goes to zero, without, I think, making the case. While he convinces me that the "1-cosx gap" goes to zero faster than the arc length, he doesn't show that it goes to zero fast enough. For example, if it went to zero 10 times faster than the arc length, the limit would approach 1/10, not zero.   I'm comfortable with his argument about (sinx)/x going to 1 and have in fact used that argument to defend the "small angle" approximation in Physics. (Larson 3rd edition, pg. 81 however, gives a rigorous explanation using limiting cases of  triangular areas bounding the section of the circular area swept out by the angle, and then applying the squeeze theorem, (1-cosx)/x is left as an exercise.   But once you have the limit of (sinx)/x going to 1, just multiply top and bottom of (1-cosx)/x by (1+cos), the numerator becomes (sinx)^2  and the expression becomes:  [(sinx)/x] [(sinx)/(1+cosx)], first factor goes to 1 and the second to zero. It's good to review properties of limits for this.  Where fault can be found, the good is often ignored. MIT and the professors involved are doing a GREAT public service by constructing these online courses. I'm amazed at the breadth and complexity of the courses offered. I deeply thank all of the MIT people involved in this. The examples and problems done in the class are excellent. I find many of the proofs easier to follow than in some texts. Thanks Professor Jerison!.

24:27 the author explains that since 1-cos(theta) goes to 0 while theta goes to 0 and considers this a proof. This is not. Because theta goes to 0 also. This limit can't be proven geometrically, because both quantities are going to 0 and even if 1-cos(theta) is presumably much less then theta, it doesn't mean the ratio of them equals to 0, from this geometric construction. Maybe it is equal to 0.0000000000001. So, unfortunately the lim (1-cos(theta))/(theta) = 0 remains mathematically unproven. The prove can be derived from the first remarkable limit (sin(x)/x -> 1) and fact that cos(x) = 1-2*sin(x/2)*sin(x/2). I leave the proof to the reader as a 2 minutes home work.

Think think his proof at 22:38 is unclear. cos(t) is not represented by the green line, rather it is the distance from the center of the circle (or tip or the arc) along the radius to the point where the green line meets the radius line. cos(t) approaches 1 as (t) approaches 0, and hence cos(t) - 1 approaches 0.

You don't have to memorize precisely how to start the addition rule for sin. You just have to remember to include the two possible pairings of cos and sin with a and b, and add them up. The order does not matter because of the symmetry.

No. Because here you have a fixed ratio of 1:2 between the numerator & denominator. But in case of (1-cosx)/x; the ratio will keep going upward as x approaches 0.

Limit of x/2x as x approaches 0 is 1/2. If you add an infinitely small amount to x (the limit from the right) then it is essentially 1/2. If you subtract an infinitely small amount from x ( limit from the left) you end up with 1/2. So the limit as x-> 0 is 1/2.   You could also simply cancel the terms and have  x/2x 1/2 limit x-> 0 = 1/2

And limit of sinx/x can also be proved easily, this way:   sin x < x < tan x   ; this is from the picture the professor has shown.   dividing by sin x,  1 < x/sin x < 1/cos x;     1 > sin x/x > cos x;   taking the limit x-->0 we see that sin x/x tends to 1.

Very good explanation 👍! And there is another method we can do this intuitively. In the case where x approaches 0 in the expression of (cosx-1)/x, one can find the value of the expression using geometric intuition.  When "angle x" approaches 0 then the arc length "x" becomes equal to sinx, just as Professor explained in the video. But (cosx-1)/x is another nut to crack.  Let there be a single triangle made by the radius of the unit circle and the x-axis with hypotenuse "H", adjacent side "A" and opposite side "P". Let the angle made by the radius to the x-axis be "x". Now let's take a look at (cosx-1)/x  We know from Professor's explanation that Arc length "x"= sinx (when x approaches 0), so put the value of x=sinx in (cosx-1)/x, and we can write (cosx-1)/x as:  (cosx-1)/sinx Rearrange it as:  (Cosx/sinx) - (1/sinx) Note that (Cosx/sinx)=A/P and (1/sinx)=H/P {basic definitions}  (cosx-1)/x= (A/P)-(H/P)=(A-H)/P  Now take a look at Hypotenuse and the Adjacent side. As angle x gets smaller and smaller, Hypotenuse moves towards the adjacent and when x becomes infinitesimally small, Hypotenuse "H" will nearly become equal to Adjacent "A" ( or you can say that "H" will nearly superimpose on "A")  Therefore H=A for a very small angle x. So : (cosx-1)/x       =(A-A)/P=0  P.S》I thought about sharing this because there were a lot comments regarding this problem. I'm not trying to act like a nerd or genius, as I have been learning calculus for only some time and and it is pretty obvious that my skill is infinitesimally weak with respect to that of the Professors of MIT. This is what I've learnt from his geometrical approach.
Brother we have so many ways to prove it by using various trigonometric identities.. It's all about the understanding of geometric proof

he does make a case for it though. Essentially if you rescale the picture so as to make the arc length constant, the two radii that enclose the sector of the circle approach two parallel lines as theta goes to 0. So that the arc approaches a line, and the gap between the bow and the bowstring goes to zero *even after rescaling*, which is the key fact, because rescaling corresponds to dividing by theta.

The variation between them is actually not linearly related and hence it will be zero. But I agree with your point that this is very qualitative and cannot be concluded geometrically.

I think his proof was thorough. The radian theta length becomes closer and closer to the green line in length as theta approaches 0, whlle the gap approaches 0. The reason why it's not 0/0 is because even though they're both approaching 0, the vertical arc length is approaching the vertical line, while gap is approaching 0. This is because if you look at the equation of the unit circle x^2 + y^2 = 1, when a number being squared increases (x in this case), it increases faster and faster, meaning that y has to decrease faster and faster as x increases by a fixed amount, in order for their sum to equal 1 as y approaches 0 (the limit we're looking at). So, as the gap changes at a linear rate, the arc is becoming infinitely more steeper until it is almost exactly straight line with a non-zero length right before the gap is 0.

Can Coteli +Dimicho Karakashev  Bit late here, but just before the 'Remarks', he shows how to differentiate sin(x) and then cos(x) and shows that the derivatives are cos(x) and -sin(x).  The only way he managed to do that, was by using the nice fact that (cosx - 1)/x goes to 0 and that sinx/x goes to 1.   His next point in the remark is, that if you take the limit at x=0, you can prove the two handy statements above. Therefore showing that (cosx - 1)/x goes to 0 and that sinx/x goes to 1 (USING THE LIMIT AT 0), he can then differentiate cos(x) or sin(x) using these nice facts.   In other words, after taking the limit at 0, you can prove the 2 handy statements, which in turn are used when doing the general differentiation for cos or sin.   Did any of that make any sense?

+Lester Sandles General derivatives for sinx and cosx are drafted with the differential quotient, but they are dependant on statements A and B whose values are unknown(or not proven) at the time. The statements A and B are derived from taking the limit Dx -> 0 at x = 0 of sinx and cosx, which is equal to calculating the derivative at x = 0. Thus if you know the derivatives at x = 0, you can use the 'general' derivatives because A and B are known. Am I in the right direction?  What is unclear to me is how you know statements A and B were actually sin'(0) and cos'(0).

Hey, I guess you probably have already figured that out, yet I've posted the answer on the question: http://math.stackexchange.com/a/1850818/164272 and I'll duplicate what seems an explanation to me here:  by 'all values of d/dx (sin x), d/dx (cos x)' prof. Jerison just meant the analytical formulae of sin'(x) and cos'(x). Id est, if we know the formulae, clearly we can calculate the value of the derivatives at each point (all values).  In the beginning of the lecture prof. Jerison derived these formulae if only the hypotheses A and B were true (he hasn't proved them so far).   At the place in question he's just shown that basically sin'(0) and cos'(0) by definition are equal to l.h.s. of the equations for B and A correspondingly.   Hence, if only we would know the values of sin'(0) and cos'(0) somehow, we would get the derivative formulae proven.  The expressions are believed to produce 0 and 1 and that is being presumed almost implicitly. That may be a source of confusion from my point of view. Still there's no inconsistency as those are merely 'remarks', i.e. sort of intuition behind the derivation which could be clearly stated as (in a direct order of construction):  1 prove that d/dx sin (0) = 1 (using definition) 2 prove that d/dx cos(0) = 0 (using definition) 3 prove that sin x / x tends to 1 at 0 (using 1) 4 prove that (cos x - 1) / x tends to 0 at 0 (using 2) 5 derive sin'(x) and cos'(x) (using 3 and 4)

@brayosaintdead note that the geometric proof is conditioned for theta = curve length in radians. that's why limit of sin(θ)/θ tends to 1 as θ --> 0, for the ratio between the vertical length of the cord (sin θ) and the curve lenght (θ radian) = 1. However for  (1 - cos θ) / θ, where the horizontal distance from origin to the cord is cos θ. The ratio between the gap (radius - cosθ) and curve length (in θ) ---> 0, for the gap is much shorter than the the curve length, and thus goes to zero faster
